coredata.dc:title: Observation of novel intermediates from CH3SH decomposition on Pt(111) with HREELS and NEXAFS
coredata.dc:creator: Koestner, R.J.
Stöhr, J.
Gland, J.L.
Kollin, E.B.
Sette, F.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Temperature-induced decomposition of methanethiol (CH3SH) on the Pt(111) surface causes the formation of two new surface intermediates, thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thioformaldehyde (SCH2). Both the adsorbed thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thioformaldehyde (SCH2) intermediates exhibit novel tilted geometries. The partial decomposition of SCH3 to form a stable SCH2 species contrasts with the behavior of adsorbed methoxy (OCH3) which decomposes completely with increasing temperature to form CO and H2 on the Pt(111) surface.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 120; number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 Óctober 1985 OBSERVATION OF NOVEL INTERMEDIATES FROM CH3SH DECOMPOSITION ON Pt(111) WITH.HREELS AND NEXAFS RJ_ KOESTNER' Department of Chemistry. University of Califorñia, Berkeley. CA 94720, USA J. STÖHR'-, J_L. GLAND, E_B_ KOLLIN Corporate Research Science lnborarories, Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Annandale, NJ 08801. USA and F. SETTE 3 National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton. NY 11973. USA Received 14 February 1985; in final form 24 June 1985 Temperature-induced decomposition of methanethiol (CH3SH) on the Pt(III) surface causes the formation of two new surface intermediates, thiomethoxy (SCH3) and Vtioformaldehyde (SCH=)_ Both the adsorbed thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thioformaldehyde (SCH=) intermediates exhibit novel tilted geometries. The partial decomposition of SCH3 to form a stable SCH= species contrasts with the behavior of adsorbed methoxy (OCH3) which decomposes completely with increasing temperature to form CO and H= on the Pí(111) Surface. The decomposition mechanisms and adsorbed intermediates for sulfur containing hydrocarbons on metal and metal sulfide surfaces have become a key issue because of the importanca of selective C-S bond activation in catalytic hydrodesulfurization (HDS) processes [1]. In this paper, we demonstrate the effectiveness of combining high-resolution electron energy loss (HREELS) and near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy tõ characterize the molecular bonding and structure of adsorbed surface intermediates. The sequential dehydrogenation of methanethiol (GH3SH) adsorbed on a Pt(111) surface results in the formation of two new adsorbed surface species, thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thiofonnaldehyde (SCH2). '. Present address: Texas Instruments, Central Research Laboratories, Dallas, TX 75265, USA. Present address; IBM Rep.,-h Laboratory, 5600 Cottle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, USA-. Present address= AT&T .Bell Laboratories, Murray. Hill, NJ 07974, USA- 0 009-2614/85/S.0330 © Elsevier Science Publishers B.V_ (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) The thiomethoxy formed during the first dehydrogenation step adsorbs with a highly tilted S-C bond. In contrast, an HREELS study [2] of the methoxy (OCH3) species on Pt(111) suggests an O-C bond normal or nearly normal to the surface. In inorganic thiomethoxy and methoxy complexes, similar bonding differences are attributed to the larger size of the sulfur atom. The thioformaldehyde formed in the second dehydrogenation step bonds to the surface with both the sulfur lone-pair and the molecular 7r orbitals. This bonding scheme results in the S-C bond being almost parallel with the surface. On the other hand, the corresponding adsorbed formaldehyde (OCH,) species is not sufficiently stable to be isolated during OCH3 decomposition on the Pt(111) surface [2]. Adsorbed OCH2 has only been observed during OCH3 decomposition by its decomposition-limited desorption on the less reactive Cu and Ag surfaces $_ $ Cu(110): ref_ [31; Ag(110): ref- [41; Cu(100): ref. [5]_ 285 Volume 120, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS _ 11. October 1985 The carbon K-edge NEXAFS [6] spectra were measured at the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL) with the use of the Grasshopper monochromator (1200 lines/mm grating) on beam line I-1. The spectra were recorded at grazing (E vector 20° from surface normal) and normal (E vector in surface plane) X-ray incidence using partial electron yield detection (200 eV retardation). The HREELS and thermal desorption (TDS) spectra were obtained in a separate surface science system; a more detailed account of these experiments will be published separately [7]. The base pressure of both vacuum chambers was < 1 X 10-10 Torr and the CH3 SH adsorption was carried out near 110 K. The NEXAFS and HREELS spectra were obtained from a surface which was cooled to ---110 K after heating to the indicated temperatures at 10 K/s. TDS spectra were acquired with a 10 K/s heating rate. The Pt(111) sample was cleaned with 02 heat treatments and characterized by LEED and Auger electron spectroscopy. HREELS and TDS spectra illustrated in fig. 1 indicate that a layer of SCH3 forms after heating a multilayer of methanethiol on Pt(I 11) to 255 K. TDS spectra show the multilayer of CH3SH desorbing at 135 K and the hydrogen from sulfhydryl desorbing at 200 K. Similar spectra with deuterium labelled rnethanethiol (CH3SD) confirm that this low-temperature hydrogen peak contains all the sulfhydryl and-no methyl hydrogem. The resulting HREELS spectrum corresponds closely to the vibrational spectrum of the thiomethoxy ligand in (CH3)3 Sn(SCH3) [8] as shown in table 1. The S-H bond cleavage is also clearly indicated by the disappearance of the S-H stretching (2570 cm 1) and bending (820 cm-1) modes. NEXAFS spectra for SCH3 are shown in fig. 2a; they were taken after heating to 230 K. For both incidence angles the spectra are dominated.by a single resonance (peak B) near 288.0 eV. Peak B is assigned to a transition of a C is electron to an antibonding carbon-sulfur orbital of or symmetry (Q~s)_ Peak B can equivalently be described as a multiple scattering resonance of the photoelectron between the excited carbon atom and the nearest neighboring sulfur atom [11] _ A similar C-S a` resonance at 287.5 eV has been observed for multilayer and monolayer thiophene (C4H4S) on Pt(111) [12]. In addition, the C and O K-edge NEXAFS spectra of the analogous methoxy (OCH3) species on Cu(100) also contain a single a- 286 shape resonance associated with the O-C bond [13]. The tilt angle of the S-C bond relative to the surface normal can be obtained from the variation of the Is- a¿S transition intensity at grazing (20°) and normal (90°) X-ray incidence [6]. However, the o resonance intensities must be normalized for a proper comparison. This can be accomplished by referencing the a resonance intensity to the carbon K-edge jump for the angle-independent continuum background. This . intensity jump in the background (shown by the dashed line) is similar to the atomic photoionization as illustrated in fig. 3 of ref. [14]; the general downward slope of our NEXAFS spectra is also observed for the clean Pt(111) surface. Theoretically, the intensity of the o resonance follows a simple cos2a relation where a is the angle between the E vector and the S-C bond axis [6] . The measured intensity of the 1 s - aL transition in fig. 2a is about two times larger at grazing than at normal incidence. This allows us to estimate a tilt angle of 45 ± 10° from the surface normal for the S-C bond of adsorbed SCH3. The tilting of the S-C bond is qualitatively confirmed by the HREELS spectrum for SCH3 in fig. 1, although a tilt angle cannot be determined. A tilted S-C bond orientation causes the symmetry of adsorbed SCH3 to decrease from C3v to CS or Cl_ This lower symmetry causes the appearance of two methyl rocking modes at 945 and 1015 cm-1. A similar splitting in vibrational frequencies between symmetric and antisymmetric methyl rocking modes occurs in the gas phase as the symmetry is lowered from acetonitrile (CH3CN, C3 v) to methanol (CH30H, CS) [15]. In C3v symmetry, only one methyl rocking mode should exist which is dipole forbidden. In addition, the appearance of a shoulder at lower frequency from the main methyl deformation mode at 1410 cm-1 in fig. l cannot be explained by a C3v symmetric SCH3 species since the dipole-forbidden antisymmetric deformation mode should occur at higher frequency. The HREELS spectrum for adsorbed OCH3 on the Pt(111) surface [2] shows only a single methyl deformation mode at 1430 cm -1 indicating that the O-C bond is not sufficiently tilted to give a measurable splitting in the deformation modes. Unfortunately, no splitting in the CH3 rocking mode near 1200 cm-1 can be observed because it is too close tó the intense vC0 mode at 1000 cm 1. The OCH3 group has also been studied with HREELS on the Ni(111) [16], Volume 120, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 October 1985 Pl(1 1 1) i- CH3SH(sat) TA =11 OK Electron Energy Loss Temperature Programmed Desorption Ee=3 to 4eV p=10 K/see x 330 320 x 1000 2910 530 ,015 1370 2985 670 1 400K ,410 ,290 945 11015 255K 1 11 3010 x 33 H2_ r. 1 975 1345 1460 á 620 1060 U " 725 1 N 110K CH,, x 2.5 . Ai 2570 40cm CH~SH, x 10 1 1 1 0 1000 2000 3000 - 5_0 0 5_0 10_0 15.0 Type K Thermocouple Voltage (mV) Energy LOSS (em-1) Fig- 1. HREELS spectra measured after heating a methanethiol (CH3SH) multilayer on Pt (111) to the indicated temperatures and cooling to 110 K_ Thiometholy (SCH3) arid thioformaldehyde (SCHz) species are identified at 255 and 400 K, respectively- Mo(100) [17], Ru(100) [18], Pd(100) [19] and the Cu (100) [S]surfaces; however, only on the Ru(100) surface does the measured methyl deformation mode have sufficient intensity to confidently indicate that the mode splitting is again much smaller than observed for our SCH3 group. On the Cu (100) surface, a recent NEXAFSand surface extended absorption fine structure (SEXAFS) spectroscopy study [20] indicates that the OCH3 species is tilted by 32 ± 10° from the normal, however, this species probably binds at an asymmetric site between the two-fold bridge and four-fold hollow positions- A systematic reorientation of SCH3 compared to OCH3 is also found in inorganic clusters due to the larger size of the sulfur atom. Terminal OCH3 groups [21-23] have much larger M-O-C bond angles (125- 287 00 00 0 rv N O 7 C C N Table 1 Summary of HREELS frequencies and assignments o) Tz u(S-C) 6(S-11) ps(CH3) pa(CH3) 6+(CH3) 8a(CH3) s-(C113) v(SH) v (CH) HSCH3 gas phase b) - 710 800 955 1070 1330 1445 1455 2605 2950,3015 multilayer 300 725 820 975 1060 1345 too weak 1460 2570 3010 (Cs) (d1.06) (p1,38) (d1.41) (1.40) (1.39) (1,35) v(Pt-SC113) v(S-C) 8(S-H) ps(CHg) pa(CH3) 6+(CH3) 6a(CH3) 6-(Cl13) u(SH) u (CH) n -SCH3 absorbed 320 670 - 945 1015 1290 too weak 1410 - 2910, 2985 (Cs) (1,05) (1,06) (1.39) (1,36), (1.34) . [9]. c) Ref. [8], d) Ref. [10]. °) Due to strong dn-pn bonding, this molecule nearly IIOS C3v symmetry and these modes are very weak. C K-Edge NEXAFS a) CH, ~as-,9• -` i 2301( r_14»- l 299 ° xPS 2815 °) _ _ C71~ 3eUx zeo zsõ Plnlon E.erçp (eV) il 3D0 31° Fig. 2. Carbon Iï-edge NEXAFS spectra recorded at grazing (20°) and normal X-ray incidence for a SCH3 (230 K) and SCH2 (380 K) layer absorbed on the Pt (111) surface. The dashed line indicates a smooth C K-edge absorption background which arises from transitions to states formed by hybridization of conduction band states of the metal and molecular states- 160") than SCH3 [24] (110-120°) due to stronger repulsion between the larger lone pair orbitals.of sulfur.Bridging OCH3 complexes [223] leave the carbon atom in the M-O-M plane, while SCH3 [25,26] clusters have the carbon atom tilted by about 55° from the M-S-M plane. This difference is caused by the larger covalent radius of sulfur which leads to smaller M-S-M bond angles and the need for a tetrahedrally bonded sulfur atom that minimizes the M-S "bent" bond energy. Both OCH3 [22,27] and SCH3 [28], how- ever,.are oriented perpendicular to the M3 plane.in triply bridging complexes that correspond to hollow sites on the Pt(111) surface. These inorganic analogues suggest that the adsorbed SCH3 bonds in an atop or. bridging site rather than a hollow site on Pt(111). The nearly equal size of the HZ desorption peaks _ at 200 and 305 K shown in fig. 1 indicates that adsorbed SCH3 loses a second hydrogen with further heating to 400 K. This indicates that the stable surface intermediate formed at 400 K has an average SCH2 stoichiometry. The H2 desorption rate in the 305. K peak. parallels the dehydrogenation rate of SCH3 since coadsorbed hydrogen desorbs at 200 K. A small fraction (--10%) of the SCH3 also decomposes as indicated by the CH4 desorption measured near 340 K_ The HREEIS spectrum in fig. 1 taken after heating to 400 K corresponds to a perturbed SCHz species. The agreement between matrix-isolated [10] and adsorbed SCH2 illustrated in table 1 is reasonable for all of the vibrational modes except the C-S stretching mode. The S-C stretching frequency decreases from 1050 for the matrix-isolated species [10] to 670 cm-1 for adsorbed thiofonnaldehyde. The assignment of the 670 cm-1 mode to the v(C-S) vibration follows from the low CH character of this mode (with a deuterium shift of 1 _03) and by. the even greater shift (to 560 cm-1) in v(C-S) observed for an inorganic cluster Os(>72-CH2S)(CO)Z(PPh3)2 [29] with a a-bonded thioformaldehyde ligand_ The 400 cm-1 shift in v(C-S) implies a strong interaction between the thioformaldehyde ir orbital and the metal surface. A similar interaction for ethylene adsorbed on Pt(111) has been extensively studied [30] and a shift from 1625 to 1050 cm-1 was measured for the v(C-C) mode. Even though the low v(C-S) frequency implies strong a-orbital bonding to the metal which is typically observed for parallel bonded molecules, e.g., C2H4 on Pt(111) [30], NEXAFS spectra for the SCH2 layer show a significant tilt of the S-C bond from the surface- The spectra shown in fig- 2b were measured after heating the sample to 380 K_ The two resonances that appear at 284_5 and 288.0 eV are assigned to excitation of a C is electron into the true and a~ç orbitals of adsorbed thioformaldehyde, respectively. Similar x" transitions have been observed near 284 eV for a number of unsaturated hydrocarbons in the gas phase [31] and chemisorbed on Pt(111) [32] _ The a¿.ç transition energy is the same as that for the thiomethoxy (288.0 eV). 289 Volume 120, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 11 October 1985 The appearance of the 7r* transition and its reversed polarization dependence relative to the a resonance confirm our HREELS assignment that a SCHZ species forms. The 7r* and a~ç transition intensities above the - dashed background do not vanish at either incidence angle demonstrating that the S-C bond is tilted. Since the rr*S (ac ç) intensity at grazing (normal) incidence is three to four times that at normal (grazing) inci dence, we estimate the C-S bond of SCH2 to be oriented 20 ± 10° from the surface plane. Since the assigned v(Pt-SCH2) and v(Pt-SCH3) stretching fre quencies are identical, we believe the sulfur atom of adsorbed SCH2 is closer to the surface than the carbon atom. An inclined S-C bond of 20 ± 10° allows the sulfur lone pair orbitals to interact with the metal at the expense of 7r overlap with metal d orbitals. The unexpected inclination of adsorbed SCH2 can then be explained as a tradeoff between sulfur lone pair bond ing and a-orbital bonding to the metal. In fact, the sulfur lone pair bonding may play a major role in sta bilizing the adsorbed SCH2 species. This view is sup ported by the observation that the analogous OCH2 species has not been isolated on any metal surface dur ing OCH3 decomposition. Inorgwiic analogies for lone pair bonding further support the view that lone pair bonding from sulfur may be significantly larger than from oxygen. For example, the thiocarbonyl cluster (CSHS)2Fe1(CO)3CS forms sulfur lone pair bonds with weak Lewis acids, while similar bonding does not occur for the analogous carbonyl cluster (CSHS)2Fe2(CO)4 [33]. In conclusion, adsorbed methanethiol (CH3SH) undergoes sequential dehydrogenation on the Pt(111) surface with increasing temperature. Adsorbed thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thioforrnaldehyde (SCH2) intermediates have not been previously observed on a metal surface. NEXAFS spectra indicate that the S-C bond is tilted 45 ± 10° from the surface plane for adsorbed SCH3 and tilted up from the surface plane by 20 i- 10° for SCH2. The partial decomposition of the SCH3 species to a stable SCH2 group contrasts with OCH3 decomposition on the same surface. The tilted geometry of the adsorlhád çCH3 group is attributed to the large size of the sulfur atom as found in inorganic analoguesThe nearly parallel adsorption geometry favored by adsorbed SCFI2 occurs because of a tradeoff between sulfur lone pair- and 7r-orbital bonding to the metal. - 290 We would like to thank A.L. Johnson for help with the NEXAFS measurements ás well as JA. Ho rsley and M. Sahneron for many valuable discussions. The reported work was partly done at SSRL, which is sup ported by the Office of Basic Energy Sciences of the US Depártment of Energy and the Division of Materials Research of the National Science Foundation. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Temperature-induced decomposition of methanethiol (CH3SH) on the Pt(111) surface causes the formation of two new surface intermediates, thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thioformaldehyde (SCH2). Both the adsorbed thiomethoxy (SCH3) and thioformaldehyde (SCH2) intermediates exhibit novel tilted geometries. The partial decomposition of SCH3 to form a stable SCH2 species contrasts with the behavior of adsorbed methoxy (OCH3) which decomposes completely with increasing temperature to form CO and H2 on the Pt(111) surface.
